quest_title: Two point charges separated by a distance \(\text{d}\) repel each other with a force of 9 N. If the separation between them becomes 3\(\text{d}\), the force of repulsion will be
explanation_txt:
Given,
\(\begin{array}{ll}{F_{1}=9 \mathrm{N}} & {\mathrm{F}_{2}=?} \\ {r_{1}=d} & {r_{2}=3 d} \\ {\because F \propto \cfrac{1}{r^{2}}} \\ {\therefore \cfrac{F_{2}}{F_{1}}=\left(\cfrac{r_{1}}{r_{2}}\right)^{2}}\end{array}\)
\(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Or}, & F_{2}=\left(\cfrac{d}{3 d}\right)^{2} \times F_{1} \\ F_{2} &=\cfrac{1}{9} \times 9 \mathrm{N} \\ \therefore \quad F_{2} &=1 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: A toroidal solenoid has 300 turns and a mean radius of 10 cm. It has a soft iron core of relative permeability 2000. What is the magnitude of the magnetic field in the core when a current of 1 amp is passed through the solenoid?
explanation_txt:
The magnetic field in the case is given by
\(B=\mu n i\) where,
\(n=\) no. of turn per unit length of the solenoid
\(\therefore B=\mu_{0} \mu_{r} n i \quad\left[\mu=\mu_{0} \mu_{r}\right]\)
\(\begin{array}{l}{=\left(4 \pi \times 10^{-7}\right) \times 2000 \times \cfrac{300}{2 \pi \times 0.1} \times 1} \\ {=1.2 \mathrm{T}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: If ABCDEF is a regular hexagon and \(\overrightarrow{AB} +\overrightarrow{AC} +\overrightarrow{AD} +\overrightarrow{AE} +\overrightarrow{AF} =\lambda \, \overrightarrow{AD} ,\) then \(\lambda =\)
explanation_txt:
By triangle law, \(\overrightarrow{AB} =\overrightarrow{AD} -\overrightarrow{BD} ,\)

\(\overrightarrow{AC} =\overrightarrow{AD} -\overrightarrow{CD} \)

Therefore, \(\overrightarrow{AB} +\overrightarrow{AC} +\overrightarrow{AD} +\overrightarrow{AE} +\overrightarrow{AF} \) \[ = 3\overrightarrow{AD} +(\overrightarrow{AE} -\overrightarrow{BD} )+(\overrightarrow{AF} -\overrightarrow{CD} )=3\overrightarrow{AD} \]

Hence \(\lambda =3\), [Since \(\overrightarrow{AE} =\overrightarrow{BD,} \, \overrightarrow{AF} \, =\overrightarrow{CD} ]\).

quest_title: The area of the parallelogram whose diagonals are \(a=3\, i+j-2k\) and \(b=i-3\, j+4\, k\) is
explanation_txt:
\(\Delta =\cfrac{1}{2} |a\times b|\)

But \(a\times b=\left|\begin{array}{ccc} {i} & {j} & {k} \\ {3} & {1} & {-2} \\ {1} & {-3} & {4} \end{array}\right|=-2i-14j-10k.\)

Hence \(\Delta =\cfrac{1}{2} |a\times b|=\cfrac{1}{2} \sqrt{4+196+100} =5\sqrt{3} .\)

quest_title: The function \[ f(x)=1-e^{-x^{2} /2} \] is:
explanation_txt:
\(f(x)=1-e^{-x^{2} /2} \)

\[f'(x)=-e^{-x^{2} /2} (-x)=xe^{-x^{2} /2} \]

For \(f(x)\) to be increasing, \(f'(x)>0\)

\( \Rightarrow \) \(xe^{-x^{2} /2} >0\)

\( \Rightarrow \) \(x>0\) and \(f(x)\) to be decreasing for \(x<0\).
question_plain_title: The function is:
explanation_plain_text:
For to be increasing,

and to be decreasing for .
ans1_plain_text: Decreasing for all
ans2_plain_text: Increasing for all
ans3_plain_text: Decreasing for and increasing for
ans4_plain_text: Increasing for and decreasing for

quest_title: A particle is moving with a uniform acceleration travel 24 m and 64 m in first two successive intervals each of 4 seconds. The initial velocity of particle is
explanation_txt:
First case

\(\begin{array}{c}{24=u \times 4+\cfrac{1}{2} a \times 4^{2}} \\ {\text { or, } 24=4 u+8 a} \\ {\text { or, } u+2 a=6-\cdots(\text { i })}\end{array}\)

Second case

\(\begin{aligned} 88 &=8 \mathrm{u}+\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{a} \times 8^{2} \\ \text { or, } 88 &=8 \mathrm{u}+32 \mathrm{a} \\ \text { or, } \mathrm{u}+4 \mathrm{a} &=11 \text { -mman (ii) } \end{aligned}\)

Subtracting equation (i) from (ii)

\(\begin{array}{l}{\quad(u+4 a)-(u+2 a)=11-6} \\ {\text { or, } u+4 a-u-2 a=5} \\ {\text { or, } 2 a=5} \\ {\text { or, } a=5 / 2 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}}\end{array}\)

\(\therefore\) From (i)

\(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{u}+2 \times 2.5=6} \\ {\mathrm{u}=1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}}\end{array}\)

explanation_plain_text:
First case

Second case

Subtracting equation (i) from (ii)

From (i)

or, \(\cfrac{T^{\prime}}{T}=\sqrt{\cfrac{L^{\prime}}{L}}\)
or, \(\cfrac{\Delta T}{T}=\cfrac{1}{2} \cfrac{\Delta L}{L}=\cfrac{1}{2} \times 1=0.5 \%\)

quest_title: A block \(\text{A}\) of mass 5 kg is placed on a rough table. The coefficient of static and kinetic friction between surfaces of block and table be 0.4 and 0.3 respectively. A force 10 N is applied on block then the frictional force between block and table is
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{aligned} \text { Limiting force of friction }\left(F_{f}\right) &=\mu_{s} R \\ &=0.4 \times 50 \\ &=20 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}\)

Applied force \((F)=10 \mathrm{N}\)
\(\therefore\) Frictional force \(=10 \mathrm{N}\)

quest_title: In changing the state of thermodynamics from A to B state, the heat required is Q and the work done by the system is W. The change in its internal energy is
explanation_txt:
From first law of thermodynamics, \(\Delta Q = \Delta U + \Delta W\)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta U = \Delta Q - \Delta W = Q - W\)

quest_title: Photoelectrons of energy 2 eV are emitted from a metal surface when photons of energy 5 eV are incident on it. What will be the energy of emitted photon electrons when photons of energy 6 eV are incident on it?
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array}{ll}{E_{k}=2 \mathrm{eV},} & {E=h f=5 \mathrm{eV}} \\ {E_{k}^{\prime}=?} & {E^{\prime}=h f^{\prime}=6 \mathrm{eV}} \\ {\text { From, }} & {E=\phi_{0}+E_{k}}\end{array}\)
\(\phi_{0}=E-E_{k}=5 \mathrm{eV}-2 \mathrm{eV}\)
\(\phi_{0}=E-E_{k}=3 \mathrm{eV}\)
\(\begin{array}{ll}{\text { We have, }} & {E^{\prime}=\phi_{0}+E_{k}^{\prime}} \\ {} & {6 \mathrm{eV}=3 \mathrm{eV}+E_{k^{\prime}}} \\ {} & {E_{k}^{\prime}=3 \mathrm{eV}}\end{array}\)

\(\begin{array}{l}{\text { or, } \cfrac{5 / 8}{5 / 4.5}=\cfrac{60 \times 0.8 \times s+10}{60+10}} \\ {\therefore \mathrm{s}=0.6 \mathrm{cal} / \mathrm{g}^{0} \mathrm{C}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: Dielectric constant for metal is
explanation_txt:
Dielectric constant \( K = \cfrac { \varepsilon } { \varepsilon _ { 0 } }\)

Dielectric constant, also called absolute permittivity, is the measure of the resistance that is encountered when forming an electric field in a medium. Metals have infinite permittivity as they completely negate the electric field inside their bulk. I.e. infinite resistance to setting up of field and hence infinite permittivity.
question_plain_title: Dielectric constant for metal is
explanation_plain_text:
Dielectric constant

Dielectric constant, also called absolute permittivity, is the measure of the resistance that is encountered when forming an electric field in a medium. Metals have infinite permittivity as they completely negate the electric field inside their bulk. I.e. infinite resistance to setting up of field and hence infinite permittivity.

quest_title: Two particles each of mass \(\text{m}\) and charge \(\text{q}\) are attached to two ends of a light rod of length 2\(\text{l}\). The rod is rotated at a constant angular speed about a perpendicular axis passing through its centre. The ratio of the magnitudes of the magnetic moment of the system to its angular momentum will be
explanation_txt:
The magnetic moment is given by
\(M=i A=\left(\cfrac{2 q \omega}{2 \pi}\right) \times \pi l^{2} \quad\left(i=\cfrac{q}{t}\right)\)
The angular momentum \(^{\prime} L^{\prime}\) is given by
\(L=I \omega=2 m l^{2} \times \omega \quad \therefore \cfrac{M}{L}=\cfrac{q}{2 m}\)

quest_title: A body of mass 6 kg moves in a straight line according to equation \(x=t^2-8t\) where \(x=\) displacement is in metres and \(t\) is in seconds. The momentum of body after \(t=24\) sec is
explanation_txt:
\(x=t^{2}-8 t\)
\(v=\cfrac{d x}{d t}=2 t-8\)
\(P=m v=6(2 t-8)=6(2 \times 24-8)\)

\(\qquad=6 \times 40=240 \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\)

quest_title: A bullet of mass 10 g travelling horizontally with 300 m/s strikes a block of wood of mass 290 g which rest on a rough floor. After impact bullet & block travel 15 m and comes to rest. The coefficient of friction between block & floor is
explanation_txt:
For common velocity,

\(m_{1} u_{1}+m_{2} u_{2}=\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) v\)

\(\therefore v=\cfrac{10 \times 10^{-3} \times 300+0.29 \times 0}{10 \times 10^{-3}+0.29}\)
\(\quad v=\cfrac{3}{0.3}=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\)

\(\therefore u=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}, v=0, s=15 \mathrm{m}\)
\(\quad v^{2}=u^{2}+2 a s\)

\(\therefore a=-\cfrac{u^{2}}{2 s}=-\cfrac{100}{2 \times 15}=-\cfrac{10}{3} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

\(\therefore \mu=\cfrac{F_{f}}{R}=\cfrac{m a}{m g}=\cfrac{10}{3} \times \cfrac{1}{10}=\cfrac{1}{3}\)

explanation_plain_text: For common velocity,

quest_title: The mean free path of gas molecules depends on (\(\textit{d }\)= molecular diameter)
explanation_txt:
In kinetic theory of gas, the mean free path of a gas molecule is the average distance the molecule travels between collisions with other moving particles.

Mathematically, mean free path \(\overset{\_}l\) of gas molecules is given as

\[ \overset{\_}l=\cfrac{R T}{\sqrt{2} \pi d^{2} N_{A} P}\]

where \(R\) is Boltzman's constant

\(T\) is the temperature of gas

\(d\) is the diameter of the molecule

\(N_{A}\) is Avogadro's number

\(P\) is the pressure of the gas

From the equation, \(\overset{\_}l \propto \cfrac{1}{d^{2}}\)

quest_title: 100J of work is done by a diatomic gas at constant pressure then heat supplied will be
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{dw}=\mathrm{nRdT} &=100 \mathrm{J} \\ \mathrm{dQ}=\mathrm{nCpdT} &=\mathrm{n} \times \cfrac{7 R}{2} \mathrm{dT} \\ &=3.5 \times 100=350 \mathrm{J} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: A solution which is \(10^{-3} M\) each in \(Mn^{2+} ,\, Fe^{2+} ,\, Zn^{2+} \) and \(Hg^{2+} \) is treated with \(10^{-16} M\) sulphide ion. If \(K_{sp} \) of \(MnS,\, FeS,\, ZnS\) and \(HgS\) are \(10^{-15} ,\, 10^{-23} ,\, 10^{-20} \) and \(10^{-54} \) respectively, which one will precipitate first
explanation_txt: One with lower value of solubility product has lower solubility and is precipitated first.

\(\therefore R=u t=u \sqrt{\cfrac{2 h}{g}}\)

quest_title: Kirchhoff's first law i.e. \(\Sigma I = 0\) at a junction is based on the law of conservation of
explanation_txt: Kirchhoff's Current Law deals with the conservation of charge entering and leaving a junction. It states that at a junction, total charge incoming is equal to total charge outgoing per unit time.
